comments:

Can it be a leak?

Myself and the other Mylyn committers have been running out of handles for the past 3 weeks or so.  We believe that this is not a Mylyn problem because we have used Sleak quite thoroughly to track down any leaks and have stopped showing the browser tab automatically (on 3.3 it leaks 30 handles each time it is opened).  Our current best guess is that this happens due to runtime workspaces (e.g. unit tests) not releasing handles on Windows.  You can verify this by opening your Task Manager and checking how many handles the javaw.exe/eclipse.exe process is using when it crashes.  A Windows process is supposed to be able to get to 10K handles or so.  If you're running many runtime workspaces we have noticed the handles run out at under 4000K.  Notably we were not seeing this problem until RC2 or RC3.

Moving to Platform in case anyone can lend any wisdom on this.

I think that it is worth considering whether there is a deeper problem here, e.g. with runtime workspaces somehow not releasing handles.  The error handling aspect of this will not solve the root problem, which is that normal use can cause Eclipse to run out of handles and crash.  Also, there is a chance that there is a regression here since several of us (CC'd) have started noticing this with RC builds but not previously.

Note that I'm running Vista with JDK 1.6 and I Rob, seeing this also, is running JDK 1.6 on Windows.  With JDK 1.5 I think that the handles usage in Windows might be less restrictive, although Shawn mentioned that it has some leaks (on his set up he can get to 14K handles without running out, but a thousands of Semaphore handles are leaked).

My current work-around to this is to launch runtime workbench unit tests with a VM that's different than the one I work in.

Sorry Mik, I'm confused. Are you saying that if I run our workbench unit tests, without Mylyn, that I'll see a handle leak?  (And can you narrow it down?)

>>have stopped showing the browser tab automatically (on 3.3 it leaks 30 handles 
>>each time it is opened).

Which browser are you referring to?

Was titled:
[ErrorHandling] Eclipse was closed without any questions

Unfortunately this takes hours or days to reproduce, so we can only verify that this happens when using Mylyn.  Note that we all work in a runtime workbennch and from that launch manual and unit test workbenches.  Beyond this bug report we have never heard this reported by a user.
Here is a summary of our experiences:
1) Mik: Vista from MSDN, JDK 1.6, noticing OutOfHandles when working workspace javaw.exe reaching around 4K, was happening every few hours of intensive work.  
2) Rob: XP MSDN, JDK 1.6, noticing OutOfHandles around 8K (we think this is the typical XP process limit for XP)
3) Shawn: XP from Lenovo T60, JDK 1.5, never running out, can get to 15K handles (weird since his USERProcessHandleQuota is 10K too).

The only other data point we have right now is that I haven't yet noticed this happen again since running my unit test workspaces using JRockit 1.5, but I also switched my JDK to 1.5.0_09-b03. So if this is not related to any change in Eclipse the only other idea that I have is that Sun's JDK 1.6 Update 1 changed something about the handle limit so that it is shared across Java instances and maybe runtime workspaces do not release handles on close.  

To probe further I'm going to start launching with JDK 1.6 Update 1 and work exclusively in that while launching in non 1.6 JDKs.

Thanks Mik.  

Philippe, I know you ran some leak tests towards the end of 3.3, any insight?

If you haven't already tried it, I suggest running with the Sleak plugin installed:

http://www.eclipse.org/swt/tools.php

It's still not always easy to pinpoint leaks, but here is a technique using sleak that sometimes works:
 - Startup with Sleak installed.
 - Do normal work for awhile to "warm up" the various places where handles are cached.
 - Capture a Sleak snapshot
 - Do normal work for awhile longer
 - Capture a Sleak diff and troll through the handles looking for patterns

You could also do a sleak diff immediately before and after running each manual test, to see if the test is the source of the leak.

Yes, Shawn has been profiling this with Sleak.  However, note that I am able to run out of handles at around 3,500, which seems like a fine number of handles for my workspace to be using.  So from what I can tell the problem here is not an intra-workbench leak of handles, but an inter-workbench failure for the JVM to get more handles.  My guess is that that the three of us are seeing it before others do is that we all work in a runtime workspace, which means that we have ~2,500 handles taken by the bootstrap workspace.  As another data point I am now running with the following configuration and *not* seeing any problems:
* Boot workspace (eclipse.exe): Sun 1.6.0_01-b06 
* Working runtime workspace (javaw.exe): Sun 1.6.0_01-b06 
* Testing runtime workspaces: JRE 1.5.0 and JRockit

I cannot do it now but will try to switch my testing workspaces back to launching with 1.6.0_01-b06, at which point I expect to see the bug again.  Will report findings.

Krzysztof: looks like you are running with 1.6.0_01 as well.  Did this happen when launching runtime workspaces?

On second thought, Sleak really only tracks GDI objects, rather than handles. Your handle counts do seem a bit high though. I see about 500 handles used in my self-hosting workspace after startup (Eclipse SDK I20070625), and it generally stays in the 1000 handle range.  We have had reported handle count spikes up to 10,000 or so (see bug 188456), but in that case we're not quite sure what kind of handles they were, and it didn't result in "out of handles" errors in SWT.

> 
> Krzysztof: looks like you are running with 1.6.0_01 as well.  Did this happen
> when launching runtime workspaces?
> 
Mik, yes i am using the same JVM as you (Sun 1.6.0_01-b06). 
I was able to reproduce this problem twice while working with Mylar plugin. At the first time i had ran runtime workspace, but the second time it was only boot workspace. It wasn't during lunching.

It doesn't need to be during launching, but there does appear to be a common thread of having multiple workspaces launched via the same VM.

Just so that our end of this is clear, could you please let me know the exact Mylyn (Mylar) versions that you used?  We had some minor leaks that are gone now.  Mylyn does impose some extra handle load due to all the decoration in the Task List, but we are not currently aware of any handle leaks.  Also note that if you are using the embedded IE browser you will be leaking ~30 handles per open browser, as per bug 84620.
I am using Mylar 2.0.0.v20070514-1800 and internal web browser.

(In reply to comment #13)
> I am using Mylar 2.0.0.v20070514-1800 and internal web browser.

Due to the handle leaks of bug 84620 and paranoia about JDK 1.6 or whatever is causing this bug, we have removed the internal browser tab entirely from the task editor if a rich editor is available and the user has not specified to force internal browser use.  I suggest t hat you get the latest Mylyn (2.0.0.v20070626-1000).  That should reduce or remove you likelyhood of hitting the handle limit via Mylyn within a single workbench and no others running.
Moving to forms team to see if they've had problems with resource leakage (see them on the stack).

I'm not aware of any leaks in ui forms which could cause this. We also haven't changed anything in forms since RC1 so if the problem only started in RC2 that suggest that the problem is elsewhere. 

I'm not sure how to proceed with this bug - without more evidence that forms was the problem I would not know where to start. Who would be most qualified to track this down?

Generally speaking, the stack trace from a resource exhaustion is not a reliable indicator of the source of the problem. I.e., just because there was some forms code in the stack at the time the process ran out of handles, doesn't suggest that forms is the culprit here. If many people are seeing the problem, and there is nearly *always* forms code in the stack, that would be a stronger indication. I'm not sure if that's currently the case.

The only clear pattern currently is that the error happens under heavy use of Mylyn... I suggest that unless the problem can be reproduced without use of Mylyn, they'd be the best ones to hang onto the bug for now.
Reassigning to Mylyn

I will attempt to create a test case where this happens without Mylyn, but won't able to do so for at least a couple of weeks.  It seems very unlikely to me that Mylyn is the root of this problem because, summarizing points made above:
1) We have done detailed Sleak analysis and know of no leaks (other than browser problems discussed in my comments above, fixed for 3.3.1).
2) When this was happening to us a Eclipse launched via PDE that would use up too many handles in a unit test suite would make the Eclipse it was launched *from* crash.  In other words, on our setups (mine is Java 6, Vista) the handles somehow end up being shared between VMs.  Since I now launch test suites in JRockit I never see this problem anymore.

Here is what I plan on trying when I get a chance to investigate:
* Set up a clean Eclipse and run it with latest Java 6 runtime
* Make a unit test that launches browser indefinitely, run as runtime workbench
* Let run until out of handles 
* Start launching browsers in original workbench and expect it to die

I have seen the this problem several times in the past. Eclipse sometimes does a panic shutdown and sometimes it just behaves strangely. In my case (on two different machines) not only eclipse runs out of handles, but windows. This has strange effects like: I can't open any menu or programs crash at start time.

In those cases it usually helps to close some applications. I have 2GB of ram and I think the total number of handles windows XP can deal with seems limited....

For me it feels like the out of memory problems, where adding more more heap memory via -Xmx does not help because its runs out of perm space and -XX:MaxPermSize is the solution. (http://michaelscharf.blogspot.com/2006/08/eclipse-was-hanging-my-machine.html)

I'm not saying it is a perm space problem, but there might be handles leaking that are not visible via sleak. 

It was more a problem of the 3.0 milestones. With 3.0 I have seen it only a few times.....

It just happened to me after opening a lot of task editors (20+).

I'm using Eclipse 3.4 M2, jdk 1.6.0u03, Windows Vista, 2GB.

I'm not a SWT expert, but is this caused by a lot of widgets being created? It is known that Mylyn's task editors create a lot of controls, and it increases by the number of comments (bug#206568).

Willian: our use of handles does grow with number of comments.  On a typical machine it should be fine for you to have dozens of editors with hundreds of comments open if all you have open is that one Eclipse.  But we will be addressing this by making the rendering of old comment date ranges totally lazy.  We'll put our latest profiling of task editor handle use on bug 206568, and do plan on reducing the per-comment performance hit for Mylyn 2.2 (likely only rendering old comments on demand).  In practice, in my experience it is very unlikely that the task editor would the cause of your running out of handles.  When I'm doing bug triage (i.e. working with no task active) I'll quickly get into a state where I have several dozen task editors open with dozens of comments reports each.  

All: I finally tracked down part of the handles problem I was discussing above, and it's quite weird.  If I'm running Adobe Photoshop or Illustrator (CS2) my Eclipse VMs will max at around 4000 handles, which is well below the typical Windows max.  If those applications are closed everything is fine.  Note that my high handles usage is because I tend to have many browser windows open in Eclipse, so it is 'normal' for me to get near 5000 handles.   It looks like this only happens on Vista, because I never saw this problem with the exact same setup.  

There might not explain the problems I detailed in comment#19, but my current guess that the reason that I was seeing this, and other plug-in developers using the Sun VM aren't, is that the total amount that Windows would allocate to all my javaw.exe's was way too low for launching multiple runtime workbenches.  With Photoshop closed I can happily work with multiple runtime workbenches going.
There are no more resources leaks in Mylyn that we are aware of.  The remaining optimization is to reduce the amount of handles used by the Task Editor, which is being tracked on bug 206568.
I created Platform bug 211124 for follow up on some of the points made in my comments above.

Just a thought. Make sure you are not hitting any OS limit:

http://blogs.msdn.com/oldnewthing/archive/2007/03/01/1775759.aspx

Recently I found out that Eclipse view on XP can have only 40 nested Composites - and attempt to create another results in SWTError: No more handles
Probably same thing can happen on menus - not tested.

It might be worth checking the nesting on most complicated forms you produce.
Thanks Maciej.  It's not likely to affect this case, but that's very useful information.
